div.head: BAGHDAD RAILWAY BOHEME
div.p: M, André Cheradamo, in an article in th,' "Energie Française,"makes a strong sppea I In favour of the urgency of giving the Baghdad Railway the international character which in many quarters it is recognised that it ought to have. He recalls tho fact that the arrangement between the Anatolian Railway and the Ottoman Government, which is the charter of the future line, places it under a purely German hegemony. The German campaign carried on with the object of securing the issue in France in May. I903,of several hundred million franc' worth of shares in the Baghdad Railway had to be abandoned owing to the intervention of the French Government,whicKafter a discreet exchange of views between London and Pari», recognized the enormous importance of the question. M Cheradame adds that the syndicate interested in tho scheme includes French contractors and financiers. He, however, warns Frenchmen who may think of inventing in the line that it cannot pay for at least ten or fifteen years after i s completion. This would necessarily lead to a temporary depreciation of their shares sufficient to cause French holders to re-sell them to the Germans, "who would thus do an excellent stroke of business financially after succeeding in an admirablo political operation." He further gives his reasons for believing that Turkey will never be able to pay a kilometric guarantee on a line of suchgreatlength.lloasks whether Franc-should open her market to an enterprise which in existing conditions would expose French inveatora to serious loss. Farther, should she facilitate an enterprise tending to confirm the absorption of Asia Minor by the Germans and their commercial aud political penetration in tho Balkans and Central Europe ! Die question of the Baghdad Railway is, he contends, of the greatest political importance, not only for Europe, but for the whole world, since it» realization in existing circumstances would be equivalent to the extension of German political and economic influence from Hamburg to tho Persian Gulf.

.Setting aside nil idea of systematic opposition to the principle of the Baghdad Railwav, M. Cheradame maintains that there is still tim-to try to prevent it from remaining pred-> minantly German. It must, he says, assume the genuinely international character which can alone place it upon a solid financial basis ami make it serve the interest of all, instead of a formidable conflict. Who, heasks. in addition to Germany and Turkey ought to form part of the international syndicate? First ..fall Russia, who is threatened by the new railwavin the south of tho Caucasus, then England; who is interested in seeing that tho shortest route to India should not be utilized against lier by Germany,a possible adversary,and, finally, Frence, whose considerable interests of all kinds are threatened with destruction hy Germany. He adds "Germany could not possibly take offence at a campaign in favour of interna tiomzhzing the Raghdad Railwav scheme. She

div.head: Editor
div.p: Mahmond Eff. Taber Haki, Editor of "Al-Djarideb el Isbonieh" and author of '-The Virgin of Danishwai," has been arrested in Cairo on charges of fraud.

div.head: Khedivial Sporting Club.
div.p: With the kind permission of the Officers Commending, Regimental Bands wilt play at the Khedivial Sporting Club, Tuesdays and Thursdays, throughout the season.

div.head: Thanksgiving service,
div.p: In accordance with the proclamation by the President of the United States of America, a Thanksgiving Service will bo held at the American Mission Church, Cairo, on Thursday next, 29th inst, at 10.30 a.m.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Four more cases of plague, three fatal, have occurred among members of the same family , at Ghirgeh. which has already been so much decimated by the peat. Of the four one is! under treatment at Ghirgeh Hospital.

div.head: Ministry of the Interior.
div.p: "It has hero rumoured that a serions frand has been perpetrated at the expense of Ministry of the Interior. On enquiring at the Ministry at Cairo thia morning formed that nothing is known of any each matter.

div.p: Mesdames Nifiwa Ali Mohamed Nafoussa Tewfik, Victoria Makbail, and Tafidah Boutros, midwives; Gioseppa Luca. Reinhnld Wnlschner, Jean J. Gyras, Richard Steele. Ibrahim Fahmy Mankariua. Sonrial Bootor. Hafir Mohammed, Ahmad El-Sobky, Mohamad Fouad Garas Qirgis El Dahh. and Ahmed Hamdy, physicians, have been authorized to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court
div.p: Mr. Cator, Judge of the Supreme Consular Court in the Levant, is arriving here from Constantinople at the end of this month, or the first week in December. During his stay in Cairo he will try three criminal cases, one for stabbing, another of coining false money, and the third is that of the Maltese postal employé who is charged with embezzlement and who will be defended by Dr. Scortino, LL.D.

div.head: Traveling Hospitals.
div.p: It is not for lack of benefits conferred that the British Occupation fails of popularity in Egypt. One of the characteristically humane provisions of alien medical science of which the Epyptian Government has been able tn avail itself through the generosity of Sir Ernest Cassel is that of travelling hospitals for the alleviation of the corse of Egypt—ophthalmia. One of these travelling hospitals, under the direction of Dr. Macallan, is enthusiastically described in the French periodical "La Nature." The article is well worth reading.

div.head: Anti-Tuberculosis League.
div.p: The Alexandria committee of the Egyptian Anti-Tuberculosis League has acquired The Espérance Dispensary in Midan No. 20. and has appointed to it M. L Chiara, a certificated chemist. The dispensary has been acquired chiefly for supplying the wants of the patients tended by the league, free of charge ; though it will also have a public service. The chemicals and drags sold at thia pharmacy are of the bust, and should attract considerable customers. Doctors are specially requested to recommend ft to their patients, and to tend to it such specialities which they receive from Europe as they do not need.

div.head: wrestling Championship.
div.p: The wrestling contests which, under the auspices of The French newspaper "Anto," have been interesting Cairenes at the .Abbas Theatre, will be continued at Alexandria at the Alhambra, the first to take place on Wednesday evening next A large number have already entered for the bonis. Oettinger, the German champion, whom Font had some difficulty in bringing down, has again accepted to try con-olueioDs with the world's champion. Ahmed Aly, the local champion, who was not beaten in Cairo, will take part in the final. Karl Cylis, we hear, is in great form, and Van der Berg, the Dutch champion, is training severely.

div.head: Soldiers and Sailors' Families' Association
div.p: A |cif'irmanco is to he given at -ihe B-'ff-I ' Tower Music Hall on Wednesday noxt, 2Hth .in.',, io aid of tho funds of tho Suld-'ers ' and Sailors' Families' Association. This benefit Wii he under the patronage nf the 0. C. of the Army of Occupation nt Alexandria. 'The performance will be an excellent one, and one of the items will he a fencing four-eminent in which the must skilful local amateurs have promised to take part. There will also be a first class performance by a troupe of variety artistes. Tickets can be obtained at Ramanelli's stationery establishment, Saint Mark's Buildings, opposite the Bourse. '

div.head:
TANTAH STATION.
GREAT EXTENSION PROPOSED.
div.p: Thb Bgyptian State Railways propose mak-mg important extensions and improvements in tbo railway station at Tantah, and the work will bo ccuiminced early in Ihe coming year On Fiiday last a deputation r f lbs chiefs cf the various departments of the Government Railways paid an official visit to that Deltaio city and decided in ontline as to the pro gramme that was to be followed. The station will bo almost comploto'y transformed and O'lloha1 and up Io date strcctnro is to replace the existing small, nncomfortable, and congested station, which has been fonnd totally inadequate to meet the vast and growing traffic. The signalling arrangements are all to be altered, and a huge electric power hoofe is to be built in order to light up all tho goods sheds, locomotive works, and other paraphernalia of a great railway jnnotion. The new policy of decentralising as mnoh as possible the Uovornment Railways will have great results at Tantab, and a large amonut of repairing work will in fntnre he undertaken

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: Al-Zaber" states that Orman Bey Mortada, the new counsellor to the Alexandria Mixed Court,will probably be appointed Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of Justice on the first occasion that any change occurs in the positions of under-socretaries.
The Ministry of Jnatice has selected the judge of Abdeen Summary Conrt to deal with cases which are brought in future against children under 15 years of age.

div.head: BELGIAN AGENCY IN CAIRO.
div.p: A Havas telegram from Brussels states that M. D'Hestroy, Belgian Minister at Athens, succeeds M. Maskens at Cairo, the latter being transferred to Rome.

div.head: GERMANY AND THE SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: Mr. Charles M. Pepper, who was sent to Egypt by the U.S. Government to inquire into the operations of the Suez Canal, reports that while the construction of the canal may present little in the way of suggestions for America in overcoming the engineering difficulties of the Panama waterway, its administration and operations afford instructive precedonts. significant feature of the Suez Canal traffic at the present time is the evidence it affords of Ihe growth of the German merchant marine and the expansion of German commerce.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: Tho "Correspondance Politique" publishes the following —

"Tbe scheme of revising ihe Capitulations in Egypt eonoeived by Lord Cromer is beginning to take form, and the Chambers of Commerce of Cairo and Alexandria havo been requested l.y his Lordship to give their views on the subject.

"The British Government has also received a mémorandum from Lord Cromer indicating the m-ans which in his opinion would bo susceptible of efficaciously circumscribing the Anglophobe and Nationalist agitation of which Egypt ia the theatre.

"Tho proposals contained in the said memorandum aro now being examined in competent quarters ; and the proposals aim more especially at a crrlain number of admi-nistratina measures holding oat to the Government and tho Tribunals the means of combating more energetically than heretofore tho fomen-t >rs of disorder and inciters of pnblio opinion."

div.head: THE TOURIST SEASON
div.p: The first large excursion patty of the pre sent season arrived yesterday at Alexandria by the steam yacht Argonant The party consista of 130 tourists, nndor the charge of Mr. Edward Loon, brother of Dr. H. 8. Lonn. The advanos agent. Mr. F. G. Harman, who hu been in Egypt for some days making Ihe necessary arrangements, accompaniea the party and they leave by special train today for Cairo, where they remain nntil Thursday next, re-embarking here on the afternoon of that day f r Catania and Versailles.

On arrival at the Capital the party will be divided between the Continental, Eden Palace, d the New Khédivial hotels. The well- known river steamer Puritan, belonging to 'he Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company. has been chartered for a trip to Sakkara on Wednesday.

Amongst the large number of passengers arrived hy ibe Argonant is the Rev. Prebendary Ing-am, who is this year's Grand Chaplain of English Preemasonry. Another interesting fact to mention is that Mr. Edward Lenn a few years ago cycled round the world in the company of two or three other gentlemen, and it took two years to accomplish this fea'.

div.head:
EGYPT AND CYPRUS.
LIMASSOL STEAM NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: On Saturday afternoon Messrs. Pilavaohi gave a very pleasant "at home" on board the S.8. Salamis in Alexandria harbonr. Thia ia one of the fleet of steamers be'or ging to ihe Limassol Steam Navigation Company, which was founded by Messrs. Pilavachi in 1905 in order to develop the commercial and passenger traffic between Egypt and Cyprus.

The compauy started with a capital of £20,000, which was subscribed hy the members of tho Pilavaohi family and a nui of Greek merchants interested in the export ard import trade between their island and this country. A few months ago the capital was increased to £50,000, which was entirely subscribed by the original shareholders.

The company only began running the steamers of its Egypt-Cyprus lice daring this summer. The fleet at present consists of the Lefkoaia (1,400 toos, 11 knots), the Cypros (2,2' 0 tons, 10 knots), and the Salamis (1,500 tons, 15 knots.) The last vessel was purchased only six weeks ago from the Aberdeen Line and used to ran between Aberdeen and London. Tho company has a regular weekly departnre on Tuoedays from Alexandria and on Fridays and Wednesdays in alternate weeks respectively from Limassol. All the steamers tonoh at Port Said. The Salamis and Lefkoaia are lor the passenger service, while the Cyprus is far cargo ; all these boats are British made, hiving been purchased io England. The company is contemplating buying another passeoger steamer of 4,000 tons in England, and will from time to time make farther additions to thoir fleet as the trade develops.

Tbe greater part of the trade between Egypt and Cyprus will, the company believe, fall into its hands, as the local Greek traders in Egypt and Cypras, who are interested in the trade between tho two countries, are shareholders. The Government ol Cypros give nnusl subvention of £5,000 to the com-
pany for carrying the mails.
Among the projects of the company is one for starting a subsidiary Hotel Tract which develop the hotel facilities throoghont
Cypras and by building up-to-date hotels on Mount Troodos and in other resorts in that beantilnl island, will attraot tourists thither.

The "At Home" on Saturday was a brilliant (□notion, and the Salamis had been lavishly prepared for the occasion. A plenteous buffet occupied the greater part of the saloon and a fine string band played a delightful selection of music. Among the many well-known persons present were Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, who was accompanied by his secretary,Benedncci Bey; M. Sootidis, Hellenio Consol Qoneral at Alexandria ; Mr. Grieg. H B.M.'s Vice-Conanl at Alexandria; Mr. Salvago, Mr. Delta, and many leading members of the Greek and other Buropean Colonies. Mr. Frangoolis, the advocate, delivered a most eloquent speech on the occasion and the success of the Company was toasted by all present
> very enjoyable afternoon was spent.

div.head: FAREWELL TO TROOPS. CONCERT AT SOLDIERS' CLUB.
div.p: A most enjoyable and pleasant concert given in the Soldiers' Clnb, Cairo, on 8atorday last, tho occasion being a "farewell" to the 2nd Battalion Royal Berks. Regiment and 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, who are leaving the command. Altboogh the battalions have been comparatively a short time in Cairo, they have managed to make themselves moat popular, and their early departure ia much regretted.

On Satarday evening the large concert room was filled to overflowing,sitting aooommo dation not being available for a large number ol members, who testified their appreciation of the musical treat provided by frequent encores. Among tho officers present were Major-General Bnllock, C.B., and Captain Dnubar, A.D.C.,Col. Gideon, Major Bennet,and Cspt. and Adjutant Lomer, Jet Lancashire Fosilisrs, Maj its Fryer and Patleraon. 6th (Inafakilling) Dragoons.

A portion of the string bind of the Inniskill-ing Dragoons, nnder the condnctorship of Sergt. Trumpeter Ptice, attended, and rendered BOme well-selected piece3, in a very pleasing manner. The piccolo solo, by Musician Banks, and the bassoon solo by Maaioian Quinn, were extremely well played, and it is a pity that one does not bave an opportunity mnoh oftener of listening to solos played by leading members of ont military bands.

Among the vocalist», 8apper Newtoo, R.E., sang very pleasingly ' Eta," and in the duet "Life's Dream is o'er" with Pte. Farrington, A.O.D., gave all-round satisfaction. Sergt. Brown, A.8.C., reooived well-merited applanse for his rendering of "Astbo.-e." In the comic element, the Harleno Brothers were well to the front, being encored again and again. Speoial mention mast be made of the valuable assistance given by Sergt. Clark, 6th Dragoons, 8ergtWills, 3rd Coldalreama, and Pte. James, A.O.D., who accompanied the songs.
The conoert was brought to a close at 11 p.m., all feeliog that it had been in every way a great aocoess.

div.head: CANON DOWLING.
div.p: Jerusalem, Bnoday, Nov. 25.

At St. George's Collegiate Church here to-day, Bishop Blyth installed Canon Dowling, D.D., as Archdeacon io Syria, and Commissary for Bastern Chnrch intercourse within the Auglioan Bisboprio in Jerusalem and the Bast.

The new archdeaoon was a student of St. Auguatine'e College, Canterbury, and was ordained deacon in 1861 and priest in 1862 by tha Bishop of Fredericton. From 1890 1897 he was domestio chaplain to the Bishop, and examining chaplain from 1899: 1897 1901 S.P.G. chaplain to the Crimean Memorial Cbnrob, Constantinople; in 1902 Canon Residentiary of 8t. George's Collegiate Chnroh. An Hon. D.D. was conferred on Canon Dowling on Jane 19, 1902, by King's College, Nova Scotia. The archdeaoon served over 25 years in the diocese of Fredsrioton.

div.head: BRIGANDAGE IN MALTA.
div.p: Highway robbery has been of late not on-common in Malta. Last week three men were tried for stopping a oab in broad daylight on the most frequented road. They were masked and armed, sod seonred some £800 in gold and about £300 in silver. The men are believed to be the real onlprite, but two of them were acquitted, and the third ia likely to gut off, on a doubt which was raised after the jury had delivered their verdiot

div.head: JANE HADING IN CAIRO
div.p: 'FROU FROL'-'

"Fron Proa" is Ihe story of a frivolous, careless woman who brings uohappiness on herself and all hers. She dies—on the stage—at the end. There we had what Jane Hadiog has not given before. She was as great as ever, moviûg os all; many people conld not help showing it, and I think every one felt it The vcice, that wonderful voice, so faint, sorrowful, all hat lifelesp, loving and lorgetting all lbs harm «bo had done and rufforod : ' Mon fil», mon fila." After hearing her it is hard even to write the words She was delightfully amn.ing in the rehearsal scene of the «eoood act, and as wonderful as ever in the scene where «he implores Sariorys not to fight M. Arnaud had less to do than nsnal, and the others hardly rose to the oocaiyon, thongh at one moment M. Grammont was really good. M. Garat (Sarto-rys) was perhaps bettor than nsnal, but he always just fills short somehow of a real effort. He and Graunmont (as Brigard) in the death soene were not at all good. The convention was badly marked and the effect nearly spoiled ; it would have been quite spoiled, had we not end ali been enchained ty "Frou Fron" herself. Yet it was perceptible all throogh that

she was not giving Ibe whole of herself to os. Probably the company are not sufficiently near her ; and then the audience : One does not wish to be always abusing one's fallow listeners, but oh that every one coold be trained to be quiet and restrained in a theatre ' Congbs, trampling, whispers, rnstiing, and almost always at the wrong mhrmfnts, all these are nothing less than exs'penRing, and yet it is so essy to avoid them. It seems to bo simply carelessness and lack of real attention to the play, that very lack of attention which the players evidently feel at once, and resent by overaoting, underacting, or even laughing at their audience. Wbat wonder ! And why trouble to do one's best to a honse that is not really attentive or oritical I Lonise (Mile Soreao) was good, distinctly better than I have seen her so far. Bnt the whole performance was on a lower level than "Sapho," except for Jane Hadirg herself.
"LE MéITRB DB FORGES."

A fall boase, bat a noisy huose, so noisy, snch coughing aod tramplingAt least one coold Bee how most of the audience resented tbo untimely and inoessant interruptions Sone of the most culpable and careless offenders were even in boxes. While on Ibis subject let curse and abuse that most vile and rasping curtain which risea in frrqoent and jarring
spa>ms. It should be seen tot

The "M.ltre do Forgaa" has a tonch of Ibe 'sixties, of mooh advertised melodrama. Some ilegioos people might call it a g'orified ndman" or whatever Mr. Caine's plsy ia ed. Happily, it has humour, and real depth, hu; it is not one of the great and subtle masterpieces. The high moral sentiments, the sublime duel verging on the ridiculous (and how these incidents appealed ') are only jnat saved by certain passages : one, notably, relieves the whole piece, the conversation of the Duke with Moulinet (it was the one situation where MM. Ragonean and Hanterive really shone). "Il est devenu préfet "encore an qui est mal tourné," is worthy of any author. Mlle Snrean and M. Arnaud were unusually excellent. M. Arnaud'» immobility suppressed passion tai-ed him above himself. He was for a time not merely the well-trained, olever man of the world ; he was very nearly great And Mile Snreau'a mannerisms and aocentnations for ouoe had their full effect The others were good after their kind. Mme. Alcide Leblano, Mlle. Macleane, M. Bary, all
had good moments.

And Jane Hading ' There we saw what the rest could not give, the intense depth and oolonr of every moment, and that io a part when she wae bonnd to exaggerate. She did exaggerate so far as so groat an artiste can do so, bnt every instant was crowded with emotion. Those wondeiful eyes, that voioe, the hands : s a history lor whosoever has felt and
can understand.
The tone, amorous, repenting, imploring, imac— is a woman is and has bean sinoe

Eve—far above all imposed odes of bononr, pride, morality— I find no word lor it. I think of the French — rà'er 1 roucouler I They suggest, but cannot reproduce. In a word, it may not he her subtlest or most moving impersonation that the nature of the play forbids ; but one almost thinks it the most wonderful. One is odoced to vaine it the more in that thongh she had moments of convention, glances, and deep tones of Sarah Bernhardt, silences when the lipe only formed the words—that is imposed, hardly natural-yet (he redeems that play which ia pure convention relieved by occasional brillianoy—that brilliancy which
Ohret gives when he forgets those to whom is his chief appeal, and—himself.
Mme. Hading came down from Cairo to day and will appear at the Zmmia Theatre ibis evening in "Frou-Frou." She will give her last petlormaoce in Egypt to-morrow night. .

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "PlETRh FRA PIETRE."

Having, under Mme Hading', auspices, gone through an exhaustive study nf tho eternal triangle in all its aspects, it is something of a rebel to turn to so admirables drama as Sudermann's "Stein unter Steinen,"—to turn, that is to say, from romsnee to reality. For it is reality, or rather realism, that forms the essence of the play. It contains, properly speaking, only one problem, but one which "gives furiously to think," namely the question whether Zarncke, in employing discharged conviot», ia right in appealing to what little bononr they may cr may not have by placing them in positions of trost, and scff«ring accordingly. For the rest the drama atonnda in unique pictures of human nature. Take any one of the men or women whom Snder* manu so excellently portrays. No sooner are we introduced to them than we can tell a1mo>t to a certainty what lies bsdore them ; no character is nntrne to itself; each pursues its coarse onswetvingly. For instance, in Aot III., the stone-masons, accustomed to Biegler's oower ing demeanour, aro astounded at his sadden outbreak, but we are not : crushed though he be by his five years' sentence lor manslaughter, we have seen sufficient of him to know that he will be unable to endure Giittliogk'a insolence. Nor should it surprise us that Gottlingk, being thwarted, will seek his revenge, that Lore will at length abandon hope cf marriage with him, the father of her child, that Marie will eventually yield to his allurements, that Strove, the pbilosophia old gaol biid, will betray the trost placed iu him, that, finally, Biegler, whose disinterested motives recall Bernard Shaw's "Devil's Disciple," will at last overcome the scruples of his fallow-workmen and chase away the shadows which haunt his past There was never a more consistent play and seldom a better eonstrootod one. Each character speaks and behaves exactly as might be expected nnder the circumstances, and thus the dramatic situations seldom take ns nnawares. But ever fresh matter for serions thought is afforded as well as admiration lor the skill wilh which the plot is unfolded. There was one slight jarring note, when Sodermann carries his realism a little too fir : Biegler, after his violent scene with Giittlingk, returns to finish his glass of beer. Now, no donbt, yonr loyal German will as soon think of leaving his beer untouched as of openly abusing the Kaiser or of sitting in a drafty room ; yet Biegler's action rankled.

As regard, the production of this play, on Satnrday, by Sig. G. Novelli'e Italian company, we will only say that, although all did their best, the acting on tho whole was below ihe standard required. Signori Novelli, Tettoni, and 8pinelli, respectively,as Biegler,Gd'tlingk, and Strove, did well enough. Sig. Greco's Zarncke was too stagey, but Siga. Vida'.i made a creditable Lore.

Any pleasure the play might have afforded ns was entirely spoilt by the persistence of the prompter to make his tinny, rançons voice carry not only to the aotors but over the whole theatre, despite the effort, of the audience and of Sig. Novelli himself to repress him. Otherwise the play was well received.

div.head:
GREECE AND ITALY.
KING GEORGE'S VISIT.
FRIENDSHIP OF TWO NATIONS.

div.p: It has been remarked that the Roumanian Minister quitted tbs oily pending the visit of King George.

King George was entertained at a banquet at the Quiirinal. King Burmanuel in touting his guest. said tbit the glories of Rome end Greece, from where art, poetry, and science had radiated, were still unforgotten. He hoped that in the future the histories of the two countries would be united. King George replied emphasising the admiration, goodwill, and fraternal feelings of the Greek for the Italian people.
The Roumanian, Servian and Bulgarian representative*, though invited to the banquet, were absent (Peuter)
King George conferred at length with Sig. Tittoni. (Bam)

div.head: ARE EGYPTIANS FANATICS ?
div.p: To the Editor op the "Eqtptian Gazette."
Dear Sir,—This question, like all otbor national quostions, is very difficult to answor, and it is certainly qoite as fallaoions to answor it in the negative as in the sffinnativo.

Bot I propose to point outsomo facts gained from persooal experience which, I hopo, will throw some light on this important subjeot. The Egyptians are roughly speaking composed of two ol-s«ee, vix —tbe Fellaheen and the modern educated Moslems. By far the majority of tho inhabitants of Egypt are Fellaheeo, and they are certainly not lanatio*, bat are enjoying the fruits of perce, tranquillity, good rule and prosperity. They are shrewd and keen bnsiness men, whose motto is "Heap op richer and boy more land"; and in fact that is what they preotioally live for.

Tbeseoond olass is composed of the educated, Boropeanly dressed natives who are mostly young men of the middle and nppor olasies. It is among this body that wo find men of the fanatioal tern of mind, who do a great deal of harm by their writing in the native press and by their inflammablo talk. Many woeld think that the educated modorn Egyptian should be the last to adopt fanatioiam, but there are two important faotors at work which produce snob dislike towards the Christians.

First is the anti-Christian atmosphere of the Government schools in which they were brooght op, and secondly the disfavonrism of the Copts in almost every Government As regards the first, I shall speak with some little authority, as it is only six yetra ago since I finished my ten years conrae in these schools, whore everybody is treated as a Moslem. For five years I attended a primary eohool where the majority of boys were of my faith, vit.. Native Christians, commonly known as Copts.

AU the eoholars need to learn the Koran (I can now recite many chapters of tbs Moslem "Bible" whiob I lesrot by heart 17 years ago). Sunday was tbe hardest day in the week, Friday was onr Sabbath ; we were tanght tho principles of Islam, we had short boors during the month of Ramadan, bad long holidays with the few Moslem boys at tbeir festivals, and at onr 'Xma* and Easter we had a day or two for each, but with a grodge, tho sobool remaining open tor the sake of the few Moslem boys. Io short Christian scholars were ignored io all the school despite the fact that they were far greater in nomber.

This onjost treatment had a bad effect on the Moslem minority and made them believe that the low classes were right in oalling the Christian "a dog" (the moat despised animal in Bgypt) which was not worthy of any con-aideratioo.
Tho we-don't-want-yon air towards the Christi» aoholara seemed to hang aboot io every Government school and oollego and I felt that air in the eeoondaty school more then any other.
If this wore the case with the bringing up of the modem Moslem and is still praotisod day after day, can we wonder at the ednosted olasses if they treat the Christian with con-tempt I

The only remedy lies in the bringing op of tho younger generation to the foil knowledge and understanding that Christians are not inferior to Moslems, that the former oan have Snnday as their day ef teat and can be instruoted in their own faith and not in a faith different to that of tbeir parents. Tbe native Christians never grnable, because they have boen need to more or leas persecutions for tho last thirteen centuries and know that, being a small minority, their ory will not be heeded to, but I most say that the perseootions of the present time are harder to bear than any other because we are roled by Christian brothors.

This brings me to the second faotor, vie, tho disfavonrism of the Copts in the Government services. This polioy is undoubtedly helping the modem Bgyptian to be a fanatic more than anything else. Ask any Moslem Effendi you come aorosa, why tho Anglo-Egyptians do loi allow a Copt to become a mondir, wakes), governor, anb-govornor or even a eohool headmaster, no matter how able the Copt may be ; and he will answer yon thus :

"The Christian faith being inferior to the Moslem faith, it follows that those who profess the latter most mis over those who profosa the former." Of coarse the Efiendi is wrong in his assertions, but then we must remember that the Modems of the Nile Valloy are notorioes fur hopeleisly m-xing religion and polities togethgr.

To prove that the unjust treatment of tho Copts isoau-iDg fanaticism among tho well to-do Moslems of Egypt, I cannot do bettor than fall back on onr history. Since tho invasion of Egypt by the Arabs, and until reoont yoars, ho rulors have alwayA been Mohamedans. We often read that doriug the reign of such and snoh a rnlor, who was kind and joat towards the Christiaus, how tho poople proipor ed and peace ruled all over the land. There again we read that daring tho reign of his son. who hated the Christians, how there were many thousands of Copts masAaorod in the streets, msny obnrohes burnt down, bow life and property were not safe and how the whole nation suffered. Thia proves olearly that tho Egyptians need always to adapt themselves aooordiog to the wishes of their misters and there is no reason at all why histflry should not repeat itself Io faut we can see that it is threatening to do so.
In conclusion I wish to point ont that if the Anglo-Egyptian Government do not take a

lesson from our history and put an end to the nnjost dealings with the native Christians, then they must expect darker days for them-solye*, for ns Copts, and fit all the Christians resident in Egypt.—Yours very faithfully,

div.head: A BRITISH DEPUTE DB LA NATION.
div.p: TO THE BdITOR OP THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—In a reoent issue yon annoonoed the appointment by the French Colony of a so-oond dopnté do la nation, and the announcement suggested to me the idea that it would confor a great boon npon the British ColoDy had we aisoaoeb a perron to officially voice our dO'ires, sentiments, and wees. Io most of the Colonies in the Levant, one or other bigwig whore position or influence aoffiee to entitle him to such a dignity, is called upon to the oolony on any State occasion ; this anawers very well ; eometimee it does not, for there are members among os who take it npon themselves to voice tbe

Colonist sentiments and desiderata, whether they'hold ~the' mandate to do so or not Witness.the oase of the British Constitution in far-away Stamboul, anent which and the wickedness of the Wicked Ten a poem was onoo published, and caused such a sensation. But that is many years ago. I won't harp back to it Our prosent need, and it is the need in faot of every Colony, is to have each a dopnty to present its weal or woe as occasion may offer : to present King's Birthday congratulations ; memorials, to deliver orations, to plead, exhort, and defend—in a word, to aot for the Colony.—Yoore, e'o.,
Xehos.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
